prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goals
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The main science goals of our proposal are as follows:
1) Characterize the magnetic morphology from polarization observations across protostellar disks and within the disk-envelope interface. We will determine whether or not magnetic fields associated with protostars are primarily poloidal or toroidal.
2) Compare magnetic field morphologies with disk properties. Theoretical studies suggest that poloidal magnetic fields suppress disk formation more efficiently than toroidal fields. A handful of observations of protostellar disk support these predictions, but lack a large, comprehensive study to connect magnetic field morphologies with disk properties.
3) Compare magnetic field morphologies with binary properties. Our observations will trace the magnetic field morphology across the circumbinary material associated with close (< 2 arcsec) binary pairs. We will look for structure or variations associated with that structure and compare that to the single systems.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We are conducting a polarization study of a large sample of embedded protostars in the Ophiuchus molecular cloud. In the current call, Bands 3, 6, and 7 are available for polarization. Band 6 provides the best data for our science goals.
Band 6 provides sensitive observations at the resolution we require for our science goals in a single array configuration. Conversely, polarization observations in Band 7, although more sensitive, will require two array configurations to achieve the resolutions we require. Additionally, dust emission in Band 7 may be optically thick at the small scales associated with disks, whereas dust emission in Band 6 is more likely to be optically thin. Finally, thermal dust emission in Band 6 will be much brighter (by a factor of ~6 assuming greybody emission) over Band 3 emission. Additionally, emission from protostars in Band 3 may be affected by non-thermal (free-free) emission, whereas Band 6 fluxes should be dominated by thermal dust emission only.

Our science goals require spatial resolutions of < 50 au, corresponding to < 0.4 arcsec at the distance of Ophiuchus. Several of our sources have known binary companions at < 2 arcsec separations. To recover well these close binary companions and the circumbinary material associated with them, we want a largest angular scale (LAS) of ~3-4 arcsec. (For those binary sources with larger separations, we will conduct separate pointings.)
A resolution of ~0.3 arcsec gives a physical resolution of ~38 au (at the distance of Ophiuchus), which will resolve > 50 au structures. For those sources with ~ 50 au disks, we can apply a more strict weighting to better resolve them. An LAS of ~3.5 arcsec (~ 450 au) will enable us to characterize the emission associated with the interface of the disk and inner envelope, which should be at scales just beyond the outer edge of the disk. Assuming maximum disk sizes of ~ 200 au, we must recover emission at > 200 au. A 450 au LAS will characterize well that scale. For those close binaries (< 150 au), we can also characterize emission at scales > 200 au from both binary companions with our proposed LAS. Thus, our chosen scales will well represent our sources.

For our science goals, we want to detect, in polarization, the inner envelope and disk of protostars. Five of our targets have known disks with typical sizes of < 200 au and masses of > 0.01 Msun. These parameters agree well with the well studied protostar L1527 (in another cloud), which has been extensively modeled. Thus, we use the parameters for L1527 (125 au, 0.0075 Msun) to characterize the expected emission for our targets. We also included a scaled-down model of L1527 (25 au, 0.0015 Msun) to estimate the expected emission associated with a suppressed disk (e.g., in the case of a poloidal magnetic field).
We used a radiative transfer code to generate both model protostars. We then ran these simulated protostars through simobserve (assuming the C36-4 configuration), finding a peak flux of 32000 uJy/beam. Since we're interested in polarized emission, we scaled down the flux by two orders of magnitude to 320 uJy/beam, correspodning to a polarization fraction of 1%. Thus, we need a sensitivity of ~64 uJy/beam to detect the peak polarized flux of 320 uJy/beam at 5 sigma.
The ALMA Sensitivity Calculator gives point source sensitivities per synthesized beam. Assuming our sources fill in the beam uniformly, we require a sensitivity of ~64 uJy per synthesized beam. The final map sensitivity, however, will vary with the weighting scheme used in the reduction. Therefore, we request a sensitivity of ~38 uJy per synthesized beam, which is nearly a factor of 2 better than 64 uJy per synthesized beam, to ensure that our sources are still well detected regardless of the map weighting. A sensitivity of ~38 uJy per synthesized beam requires 10 minutes of integration on each source, yielding a good UV coverage for each object.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a polarization survey of 32 embedded protostars in the Ophiuchus molecular cloud. We will observe our sources at resolutions of ~40-500 AU, which will sample well the polarization across their disks down to a sensitivity of 38 uJy per synthesized beam. Only a handful of protostellar disks have been observed in polarization at < 100 AU scales to date. This study is the first to survey magnetic fields in a comprehensive, homogenous sample of protostellar disks. With these data, we will identify the dominant magnetic field morphology (e.g., toroidal or poloidal) associated with the disks and compare these morphologies to the disk properties, testing our observations against theories. Moreover, our observations will also recover emission associated with the inner envelope. Thus, we will also compare and contrast the disk field morphologies with the envelope morphology. These observations will connect magnetic field morphologies in disks with star formation processes for the first time.
